title: Trump backs full release of Epstein files in sharp reversal
summary: US president backs bipartisan push to release documents amid tensions within his Republican base.

title: Russia-Ukraine war live: 3 killed in Kharkiv; Zelenskyy to meet Macron
summary: Russian attack kills three people and injures 10 in Ukraine's eastern Kharkiv region.

title: Live: Bangladesh court convicts Sheikh Hasina of crimes against humanity
summary: Hasina is being tried in absentia for crimes against humanity for a violent crackdown on student protests last year.

title: US flights to return to normal after aviation authority lifts restrictions
summary: Federal Aviation Administration says airlines can resume normal schedules from Monday.

title: Portugal, Norway book qualification spots at 2026 FIFA World Cup
summary: Portugal recovered from shock loss to Ireland on Thursday to qualify, while Norway is through for first time since 1998.

title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 1,362
summary: Here are the key events from day 1,362 of Russia’s war on Ukraine.

title: Voters in Ecuador reject return of foreign military bases
summary: Count of more than 90 percent of ballots show two-thirds rejecting the proposal to host foreign military bases.

title: Dozens killed in DR Congo after bridge collapses at copper, cobalt mine
summary: Deaths came after miners rushed a makeshift bridge at the Kalando mine in southeastern Lualaba province, official says.

title: Sinner defeats Alcaraz to repeat as ATP Finals champion
summary: Jannik Sinner beat Carlos Alcaraz for just the second time this year and defended his ATP Finals crown in Turin.

title: Chile heads to a presidential run-off between Jara and Kast
summary: Leftist former Labour Minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast set to face off in December run-off

title: DR Congo shock Nigeria on penalties to win African World Cup playoffs
summary: DR Congo reach inter-confederation playoffs for 2026 World Cup after beating Nigeria on penalties after a 1-1 draw.

title: Israel kills at least three in Gaza, as thousands endure heavy flooding
summary: As Gaza’s misery deepens, Israel’s Netanyahu reveals to cabinet that he is uncertain how long truce will hold.

title: Vote attendu du Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU sur un projet américain de résolution sur Gaza
summary: L'avenir d'un possible État palestinien à nouveau au coeur du vote d'un projet américain de résolution sur Gaza, aujourd'hui, au Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU. Le Premier ministre israélien a dit son opposition. Le nouveau projet de résolution "autorise" la mise en place d'une "force de stabilisation internationale" (ISF) chargée notamment de l'appui à la sécurisation des frontières de la démilitarisation de Gaza, du désarmement "des groupes armés non étatiques" et de la protection des civils.

title: Vote attendu du Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU pour autoriser une force internationale à Gaza
summary: Le plan de paix de Donald Trump pour Gaza, qui a permis la mise en place d'un cessez-le-feu entre Israël et le Hamas, est soumis au vote lundi du Conseil de sécurité de l'ONU. Le texte prévoit notamment le déploiement d'une "force de stabilisation internationale" dans la bande de Gaza.

title: Avant un vote à l'ONU, Netanyahu réitère une fois de plus son refus d'un État palestinien
summary: Sous la pression de ses ministres d’extrême droite, Benjamin Netanyahu a réitéré son opposition catégorique à la création d’un État palestinien, à la veille d’un vote clé au Conseil de sécurité de l’ONU. Le Premier ministre rejette fermement toute perspective de souveraineté palestinienne, malgré un projet de résolution américain qui l’évoque pour l’avenir.

title: Liban : les Casques bleus accusent l'armée israélienne de leur avoir tiré dessus à partir d'un char
summary: La Force intérimaire des Nations unies au Liban (Finul) a accusé l'armée israélienne, dimanche, d'avoir tiré sur des soldats de la paix "à partir d'un char Merkava situé près d'une position établie par Israël en territoire libanais". La force onusienne a exhorté Israël "à cesser tout comportement agressif et toute attaque" contre ou à proximité de ses Casques bleus.

title: Laetitia Bucaille : En Cisjordanie, "l’objectif est de faire se déplacer les Palestiniens"
summary: En Cisjordanie, les violences des colons israéliens s’intensifient. Hier encore, deux adolescents palestiniens ont été tués près d’Hébron, une mosquée a également été incendiée et des raids menés par des groupes de colons ont blessé plusieurs Palestiniens et détruit de nombreux biens. Ces attaques, de plus en plus fréquentes, se déroulent dans une quasi-impunité. Une situation analysée avec la sociologue Laetitia Bucaille.

title: La Finul accuse Israël de construire des murs au Liban, Tsahal dément
summary: La Force intérimaire des Nations Unies au Liban (Finul) a accusé Israël, vendredi, d'avoir "violé" la souveraineté du Liban avec la construction de murs sur son territoire. L'armée israélienne a démenti, reconnaissant toutefois avoir érigé une barrière renforcée le long de la ligne de démarcation entre les deux pays.

title: Gaza : la dépouille de l'otage Meni Godard a été rendue à Israël par le Hamas
summary: Le Hamas et le Jihad islamique ont rendu jeudi à Gaza la dépouille de l'otage israélien Meni Godard, tué le 7 octobre 2023 à l'âge de 73 ans. De son côté, l'Autorité palestinienne a annoncé que des soldats israéliens avaient tué dans le sud de la Cisjordanie deux adolescents de 15 ans, présentés par l'armée israélienne comme des "terroristes en passe de perpétrer une attaque".

title: Trump a écrit au président israélien pour demander une grâce pour Netanyahu
summary: Dans un courrier adressé au président israélien, Donald Trump a demandé qu'une grâce soit accordée au Premier ministre Benjamin Netanyahu, poursuivi dans son pays pour corruption, a révélé mercredi le bureau de la présidence.

title: Législatives en Irak : le Premier ministre sortant Mohamed Chia al-Soudani revendique la victoire
summary: Après les premiers résultats de la commission électorale donnant sa liste en tête aux législatives, le Premier ministre sortant Mohamed Chia al-Soudani a revendiqué la victoire mardi soir. La formation du prochain gouvernement irakien devrait toutefois donner lieu à d'intenses tractations.

title: Israël rouvre un point de passage "permanent" aux camions d'aide dans le nord de Gaza
summary: Les autorités israéliennes ont annoncé mercredi la réouverture "permanente" du point de passage de Zikim, au nord de la bande de Gaza, pour permettre l'entrée d'aide humanitaire internationale dans le territoire palestinien, ravagé par plus de deux ans de guerre.

title: Mahmoud Abbas à Paris : bientôt des élections ?
summary: Pour sa première visite en France en tant que chef d'État, depuis la reconnaissance de la Palestine par Paris, Mahmoud Abbas s'engage auprès d'Emmanuel Macron sur la tenue d'élections sur l'ensemble des territoires palestiniens. Les dernières datent de près de vingt ans. On va plus loin avec Patricia Allémonière et Melina Huet.

title: Gaza : les combattants du Hamas piégés dans des tunnels à Rafah, un test décisif pour le plan Trump
summary: Le sort de près de 200 combattants du Hamas, retranchés dans des tunnels à Rafah, dans une zone contrôlée par l’armée israélienne, menace de faire voler en éclats le cessez-le-feu à Gaza. Alors que le mouvement islamiste palestinien rejette toute idée de reddition, Washington craint que leur élimination sur ordre d’un Benjamin Netanyahu sous pression empêche toute avancée du plan Trump.

title: L’accord de 1968, au cœur du contentieux franco-algérien sur l’immigration
summary: La présence des immigrés algériens en France – la plus importante communauté immigrée, avec près de 900 000 personnes – tient davantage à l’histoire imbriquée des deux pays qu’à l’accord en tant que tel.

title: EN DIRECT, Gaza : le Conseil de sécurité de l’ONU doit voter lundi sur le plan de paix de Donald Trump, qui autorise une force internationale dans l’enclave
summary: Le nouveau projet américain de résolution sur Gaza évoque l’avenir d’un possible Etat palestinien, auquel le gouvernement israélien s’oppose fermement de longue date.

title: EN DIRECT, guerre en Ukraine : une attaque russe dans l’Est fait trois morts
summary: Les autorités de l’oblast de Kharkiv ont fait état de trois personnes tuées et au moins dix autres blessées dans une attaque dans la nuit de dimanche à lundi. D’après Vitali Karabanov, à la tête de l’administration militaire de Balakliïa, l’armée russe a procédé à deux frappes de missile contre le centre-ville.

title: « L’industrie spatiale française est menacée de perdre son leadership historique en Europe »
summary: Alors que l’Allemagne investit fortement dans les activités spatiales, la France, moteur du secteur en Europe, aura du mal à suivre un tel rythme en raison de faibles marges de manœuvre budgétaires, analyse Fabrice Gliszczynski, journaliste au « Monde », dans sa chronique.

title: Vacances en Albanie : quand l’hôtel cinq étoiles est démoli pendant le séjour
summary: Les touristes réveillés par le fracas de bulldozers et dont le séjour a été perturbé ont mis trois ans pour obtenir le remboursement intégral de leur voyage

title: Guerre en Ukraine : fragilisé par un scandale de corruption et par l’avancée russe, Volodymyr Zelensky cherche du soutien auprès de ses alliés
summary: En visite lundi à Paris, après un passage en Grèce dimanche et un séjour prévu à Madrid mardi, le président ukrainien veut rassurer ses soutiens européens, alors que deux de ses ministres ont dû démissionner à la suite d’une affaire impliquant également l’un de ses proches. Sur le front, la Russie est sur le point de prendre la ville-clé de Pokrovsk.

title: Reconnaissance faciale : comment les Etats autoritaires traquent leurs opposants
summary: Cette technologie, qui s’appuie sur des images de vidéosurveillance analysées par des logiciels d’intelligence artificielle, a d’abord séduit des Etats autoritaires. Mais la reconnaissance faciale conquiert aussi progressivement les pays démocratiques. Avec quels garde-fous ? Eléments de réponse dans ce podcast avec Faustine Vincent et Simon Leplâtre, journalistes au service International du « Monde ».

title: Référendum en Equateur : les électeurs rejettent le retour des bases étrangères et une nouvelle Constitution, selon des résultats partiels
summary: Quelque 61 % des votants refusent de lever l’interdiction des bases étrangères et 62 % s’opposent à la nomination d’une assemblée chargée de rédiger une nouvelle Constitution, selon des résultats partiels.

title: Affaire Epstein : Donald Trump, dans un revirement inattendu, appelle les républicains à approuver la publication du dossier sur le délinquant sexuel
summary: Le président américain, soupçonné d’avoir dissimulé des éléments l’impliquant dans ce scandale, avait jusque-là refusé toute divulgation. La Chambre des représentants est appelée à voter sur le sujet cette semaine.

title: Sale temps pour les bovins suisses
summary: Surproduction laitière, taxes américaines sur le fromage, menace sanitaire sur le cheptel, affaiblissement de la diversité des races… La mascotte des paysages helvétiques traverse une mauvaise passe.

title: COP31 : l’Australie refuse la coorganisation du sommet sur le climat avec la Turquie
summary: Si aucun accord n’est trouvé, Canberra et Ankara pourraient perdre l’accueil, au profit de l’Allemagne, de la 31ᵉ Conférence des Nations unies sur le changement climatique qui doit avoir lieu en 2026.

title: Présidentielle au Chili : la communiste Jeannette Jara et l’ultraconservateur José Antonio Kast s’affronteront au second tour
summary: La candidate de la coalition de centre gauche au pouvoir est arrivée en tête du premier tour, avec 26,71 % des suffrages, contre 24,12 % pour son rival d’extrême droite. Mais c’est José Antonio Kast qui fait désormais figure de favori pour le second tour, qui aura lieu le 14 décembre.

title: Israeli military detains at least four Palestinians in West Bank
summary:
Israeli military detains at least four Palestinians in West Bank

The Israeli forces stormed east of Nablus in the occupied West Bank, raided several homes in Balata camp and arrested three citizens, Muhammad Hamdallah Hashash, Ahmed Salah Sabah, and Iyad Kayed Hashash, according to the Palestinian Information Centre.

The military also arrested former detainee Muhammad Naji Sabha after storming his home in Anabta, east of Tulkarm in the occupied West Bank, Quds news agency reported.

title: Israeli settlers attack Bedouin community in east of Jerusalem
summary:
Israeli settlers attack Bedouin community in east of Jerusalem

Israeli settlers attacked the Bedouin community of al-Tabna, near Khan al-Ahmar, east of occupied Jerusalem, early Monday morning, according to Wafa news agency.

Local sources reported that the settlers threw stones at residents' homes and property, used loudspeakers at night and drove off-road vehicles near the community's homes to harass and eventually displace the residents of the community.

The Bedouin community has witnessed a series of attacks by Israeli settlers in recent weeks.

title: Morning update
summary:
Morning update

Good morning Middle East Eye readers,

Here are the latest updates:

  • The UN Security Council is set to vote Monday on a US-drafted resolution bolstering Donald Trump's Gaza peace plan, especially the deployment of an international force.

  •  Al Jazeera is reporting heavy gunfire from Israeli helicopters behind the yellow line east of Khan Younis city in the southern Gaza Strip.

  • Israeli military carried out six air strikes on the eastern areas of Khan Younis city, southern Gaza Strip, according to the Palestinian Information Centre.

  • Hamas spokesman Hazem Qassem said the amendments to the draft US resolution don't serve stability in the Gaza Strip, warning that the proposal effectively replaces Israeli occupation with a different form of international trusteeship.

  • The government media office in Gaza said Israel continues its "starvation policy" by preventing the entry of basic food supplies and allowing the passage of luxury goods.

title: Evening recap
summary:
Evening recap

Our live blog will shortly be closing until tomorrow morning.

Here are the day's key developments:

  • Gaza's hospitals have received the bodies of 17 Palestinians in the last 72 hours, Wafa news agency is reporting, citing medical sources. It reported that two people had been killed in Israeli attacks, while rescue teams recovered 15 bodies from the rubble.

  • This brings the overall number of Palestinians killed by Israeli forces in Gaza since October 2023 to 69,483.

  • Since the fragile ceasefire was implemented on 11 October 2025, 266 people have been killed in Israeli attacks, 635 wounded and 548 bodies recovered from the rubble.

  • The World Health Organization has reported that over 900 patients in Gaza have died while waiting for medical evacuations, which have been stalled by Israeli restrictions.

  • Gaza officials say Israel has torn through the so-called ceasefire with relentless attacks, killing hundreds of Palestinians in the month since the agreement was announced.

  • Israeli forces have shot and killed a Palestinian teenager during an overnight raid on the Askar refugee camp east of Nablus in the occupied West Bank.

  • The Israeli army said that its soldiers fired at UN Interim Force in Lebanon (Unifil) peacekeepers from a tank in southern Lebanon due to "poor weather conditions", which meant they mistook the observers for "suspects".

  • Israel’s prime minister has doubled down on rejecting Palestinian statehood, moving to calm a revolt inside his own far-right coalition after Washington backed a UN draft that gestures, however cautiously, towards Palestinian independence.

  • Palestinian officials have told Haaretz that senior figures in Saudi Arabia have quietly told the Palestinian leadership in recent days that Riyadh will not push ahead with any normalisation process with Israel as long as Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right government remains in charge.

title: Netanyahu calls illegal Israeli settlers 'law abiding' as violence sweeps West Bank
summary:
Netanyahu calls illegal Israeli settlers 'law abiding' as violence sweeps West Bank

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has tried to distance his government from the surging settler violence sweeping the occupied West Bank, insisting the attacks “do not represent the large community of settlers who are law-abiding and loyal to the state”, The Jerusalem Post reported.

He told ministers the escalating assaults were “caused by a minority”, even as documented attacks reach unprecedented levels.

The UN’s humanitarian office recorded more than 260 settler assaults in October alone, the highest monthly figure since it began tracking the pattern in 2006. Palestinians say the violence is part of a broader strategy to drive them from their land while Israel accelerates efforts to entrench its control.

Israel continues to push towards formal annexation of the occupied territory, a move that violates international law and further entrenches the system of apartheid and dispossession Palestinians face daily.

title: Israel accused of 282 ceasefire breaches in Gaza over one month
summary:
Israel accused of 282 ceasefire breaches in Gaza over one month

Gaza officials say Israel has torn through the so-called ceasefire with relentless attacks, killing hundreds of Palestinians in the month since the agreement was announced.

According to the Government Media Office, Israeli forces breached the ceasefire at least 282 times between 10 October and 10 November, carrying out air strikes, artillery fire, and direct shootings across the Strip.

The office reported that Israeli forces opened fire on civilians 88 times, stormed neighbourhoods beyond the “yellow line” 12 times, bombed Gaza 124 times, and levelled residential property on 52 occasions. It also said Israel detained 23 Palestinians from Gaza during the same period.

Despite the declared pause in the genocide, Israel has continued to block essential humanitarian aid, while destroying homes and infrastructure across the besieged territory, deepening an already catastrophic situation for civilians.

title: Israeli forces killed a 15-year-old in the West Bank, refusing aid and holding his body
summary:
Israeli forces killed a 15-year-old in the West Bank, refusing aid and holding his body

Israeli security forces shot dead a 15-year-old boy in the Far’a refugee camp in the occupied West Bank, Palestinian education officials confirmed.

The boy, identified as Jadallah Jihad Jumaa Jadallah, was a ninth-grade student at a Unrwa-run school in the camp, Wafa news agency reported.

According to local sources, Israeli troops invaded Far’a, shot Jadallah, and wounded two others. Ambulance crews were initially blocked from reaching him, and Israeli forces later labelled him a “terrorist” without providing any evidence.

Wafa added that Israeli forces are still holding the boy’s body, raising urgent concerns among families and human rights groups about ongoing abuses in the West Bank

title: Netanyahu says Gaza ceasefire uncertain as UN vote looms
summary:
Netanyahu says Gaza ceasefire uncertain as UN vote looms

New details from an Israeli cabinet meeting reveal deep uncertainty over Gaza’s future a day before the UN Security Council is set to vote on a draft plan for the besieged territory.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told ministers he “did not know” how long the ceasefire would hold and stressed that Israel is “working to conclude Phase A” while awaiting the return of three bodies held by Hamas.

National Missions Minister Orit Strock reportedly pushed back, saying, “We did not go to war only to free hostages.” Netanyahu also noted that foreign forces remain “reluctant” to enter Gaza, signalling the difficulty of assembling the proposed stabilisation force.

Although the draft plan allows for up to 20,000 international troops, it is unclear which countries would participate. Israel has already ruled out Turkish involvement. When pressed on timing, Netanyahu said, “We cannot ignore our managing of a seven-front war … the amount of time left cannot be quantified.”

title: Palestinian coalition rejects US colonial plan for Gaza
summary:
Palestinian coalition rejects US colonial plan for Gaza

Submitted by Elis Gjevori on Sun, 11/16/2025 - 19:26
Palestinian body condemns US attempt to impose foreign rule and legitimise Israel’s genocide on Gaza
Palestinian children carry their belongings past an unexploded missile in a rubbish dump at the Firas market area of Gaza City on November 12, 2025. [Omar Al-Qattaa/AFP]
Off

The National Commission for Palestinian Popular Action has issued a forceful statement on Sunday rejecting US proposals to place Gaza under an externally imposed transitional administration, warning that such a move amounts to “a new colonialism”.

The commission said any attempt to install a governing body “outside the will of the Palestinian people” violates their right to self-determination and seeks to repackage old forms of domination “under updated labels”.

It stressed that decisions about Gaza’s future must come from Palestinians themselves and safeguard the unity of the land, the legitimacy of resistance to the Israeli occupation, and the “right to freedom, resistance, and self-determination” guaranteed under international law.

A US draft resolution that is set to go to the UN Security Council on Monday is drawing sharp warnings from legal experts and Palestinian groups, who say Washington is trying to hardwire Israel’s genocide in Gaza into an international framework.

The text seeks to endorse the Trump Peace Plan, the so-called “Comprehensive Plan”, and sign off on two new bodies: a civilian transitional administration named the Board of Peace and a militarised “International Stabilisation Force”.

Normalising genocide

The draft hands sweeping powers to the Board of Peace, including oversight of Gaza’s governance, reconstruction, economic recovery, and the coordination of humanitarian operations.

Critics say the move uses the UN’s authority to normalise the genocide and impose yet another foreign regime on Palestinians.

The plan rests outside any recognised international legal framework and instead lays out a parallel order built on security control and external authority.

Francesca Albanese says Starmer helped 'manufacture' consensus for Israeli genocide
Read More »

If passed, the commission warns, the Security Council would be endorsing a system that strips Palestinians of their right to self-determination while undermining the credibility of international law itself.

While acknowledging that a narrowly defined international presence could help monitor a ceasefire and protect civilians, the commission insisted such a force must be strictly limited and “expressly prohibited from taking on any administrative or political role”. Any shift towards a disguised trusteeship, it warned, is “categorically rejected”.

The commission called on Palestinian political movements, institutions, and communities worldwide to reject all forms of external control and avoid engaging with proposals that undermine national decision-making. It urged public figures, unions, and organisations to oppose what it described as renewed colonial ambitions through peaceful and legal means.

The statement closed with a reaffirmation of its commitment to unified popular action “in defence of the rights of our people” and in support of Palestinian steadfastness until full freedom is achieved.

On the ground, Israel has kept up its assault despite the so-called ceasefire, blocking aid convoys, tightening restrictions on humanitarian access, and continuing to bomb Gaza, killing and wounding civilians almost daily.

Israel's genocide in Gaza

title: UN warns West Bank faces biggest displacement crisis since 1967
summary:
UN warns West Bank faces biggest displacement crisis since 1967

UN warns of mass displacement across West Bank as Israeli violence intensifies

  • The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (Ocha0 says the occupied West Bank is experiencing its worst displacement crisis in decades, driven by Israel’s demolitions, military raids and unchecked settler violence.

  • More than 1,500 Palestinians have been forced from their homes this year because Israel withholds building permits that Palestinians say are practically impossible to obtain. About 1,000 were expelled from Area C and another 500 from occupied East Jerusalem.

  • Satellite analysis shows roughly 1,460 structures destroyed or damaged in Jenin, Nur Shams and Tulkarem refugee camps during repeated Israeli assaults.

  • Settler attacks linked to the olive harvest have surged. Since 1 October, Ocha has recorded 167 violent incidents targeting 87 Palestinian communities, as armed settlers act with the protection of Israeli forces.

  • Israeli troops killed four Palestinians, three of them childre, between 4 and 10 November in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem. Since January, Israeli forces have killed 45 Palestinian children, nearly a quarter of all Palestinians killed in the territory this year.

  • Ocha says Israel’s prolonged military operations in Jenin, Nur Shams and Tulkarem have triggered the largest and longest displacement crisis in the northern West Bank since 1967.

  • Unrwa estimates that at least 31,919 Palestinian refugees have been driven from these camps and nearby neighbourhoods as Israeli forces continue large-scale incursions.

title: Freed Palestinian child prisoners recount torture in Israeli custody
summary:
Freed Palestinian child prisoners recount torture in Israeli custody

Three Palestinian teenagers released in a recent prisoner exchange were abducted by Israeli soldiers while seeking aid and tortured in custody, a new report has revealed.

In interviews conducted by the NGO Defense for Children Palestine (DCIP), Mohammad Nael Khamis al-Zoghbi, 17, Faris Ibrahim Faris Abu Jabal, 16, and Mahmoud Hani Mohammad al-Majayda, 17, described how they were abducted by Israeli forces near aid distribution points and transferred to the notorious Sde Teiman detention camp in southern Israel. 

They said they endured torture, beatings and starvation in Israeli custody. The trauma has left them unable to sleep, and they are plagued by night terrors and bed wetting.

One of the boys said he felt his detention had "stripped away his childhood".

Jabal, who was abducted along with his father while seeking aid near the Morag Corridor on 11 September, recalled being so badly beaten during his interrogation that his forehead “split open and required stitches”.

Read more: Freed Palestinian child prisoners recount torture in Israeli custody

title: Riyadh refuses normalisation under Netanyahu: Report
summary:
Riyadh refuses normalisation under Netanyahu: Report

Palestinian officials have told Haaretz that senior figures in Saudi Arabia have quietly told the Palestinian leadership in recent days that Riyadh will not push ahead with any normalisation process with Israel as long as Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right government remains in charge.

Their comments came after US President Donald Trump said on Friday that he was considering approving a deal to supply Saudi Arabia with F-35 stealth fighters. According to the Palestinian officials, such a weapons agreement is nowhere near enough for Riyadh to formalise ties with Israel, especially at a moment when Israel continues its assault on Gaza and openly rejects Palestinian statehood.

Israel’s opposition leader, Yair Lapid, weighed in on Sunday, insisting that advanced fighter jets had never featured in earlier discussions on a potential Saudi-Israeli agreement. “Having taken part in dozens of discussions on a normalisation arrangement with Saudi Arabia, the F-35 deal was never part of any such agreement, because it was clear that Israel's security requires preserving its qualitative military edge,” he said.

Lapid urged lawmakers to block the move. “Israel cannot, due to the weakness of the current government, give up core security interests and allow the F-35 deal to go through.”

title: “The Friendship Remains The Highest Value.” - Sponsored Content
summary:
Dr. Devin Naar, a Jewish professor of Sephardic Studies at the University of Washington, is a controversial voice whose take on Israel many may find unsettling.

The post “The Friendship Remains The Highest Value.” appeared first on The Times of Israel.

title: ICT minister travels to Baku for global telecom development conference
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Minister of Information and Communications Technology, Seyyed Sattar Hashemi, has traveled to Baku to attend the 2025 World Telecommunication Development Conference (WTDC-25), a major international gathering aimed at strengthening global cooperation in the communications and technology sector.

title: Pakistan welcomes Iran’s offer of mediation with Afghanistan
summary: Islamabad, IRNA – The spokesperson for Pakistan’s Foreign Ministry says Islamabad welcomes Iran’s offer of mediation to resolve disputes between Islamabad and Kabul.

title: Iran neither opposes negotiations nor will it abandon uranium enrichment: Senior official
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Head of the Strategic Council on Foreign Relations Kamal Kharazi says Iran does not reject negotiations over its nuclear energy program, but will not abandon its defensive capabilities or its peaceful uranium enrichment activities.

title: Iran questions Western concerns despite halt to uranium enrichment
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Deputy Foreign Minister for Legal and International Affairs, Kazem Gharibabadi, has questioned renewed Western pressure on Tehran at a time when the country is not conducting uranium enrichment.

title: Deputy FM in Islamabad to attend 13th round of bilateral talks
summary: Islamabad, IRNA – Majid Takht-Ravanchi, Deputy Foreign Minister for Political Affairs, has arrived in Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan, to participate in the 13th round of bilateral political consultations between the two countries.

title: Iran’s wushu, taekwondo teams shine in Islamic Solidarity Games in Riyadh
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Iran’s wushu and taekwondo teams have given a thrilling performance at the Riyadh 2025 Islamic Solidarity Games, grabbing five gold, three silver, and one bronze medals on Sunday.

title: VP Aref travels to Moscow for SCO Council of Heads of Government Meeting
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Iran’s First Vice-President Mohammad Reza Aref has departed for Russia to attend the 24th Meeting of the Council of Heads of Government (Prime Ministers) of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO).

title: US, allies escalate tensions against Iran’s scientific progress: AEOI chief
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Head of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran (AEOI) Mohammad Eslami has condemned the United States and its allies for escalating tensions in their ongoing campaign against the Islamic Republic’s scientific advancements.

title: Araghchi, PGCC secretary general discuss regional developments
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi in a phone call with Secretary General of the Persian Gulf Cooperation Council (PGCC) Jasem Mohamed Albudaiwi has discussed issues of mutual interest, as well as regional developments.

title: Iran condemns continued Israeli human rights violations in Gaza and West Bank
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Foreign Ministry spokesperson Esmaeil Baqaei has condemned the Israeli regime’s continued killings of Palestinians and blatant violations of human rights in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

title: Qatar receives written message from Iranian foreign minister
summary: Tehran, IRNA – Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi has sent a written message to his Qatari counterpart focused on bilateral relations and ways to expand them, Qatar’s state news agency (QNA) reported on Sunday.

title: 2026 World Cup Qualifier: Italy vs. Norway preview, stats and team news
summary: Italy hosts Norway at San Siro in a decisive World Cup 2026 qualifier. Norway aims to confirm top spot as Italy chases pride and playoff form. Read all the match details in this report.

title: Israeli drone strike in Southern Lebanon kills one
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – An Israeli airstrike on southern Lebanon has left one person dead.

title: Iran, Pakistan diplomats mull over strengthening ties
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) –Iran’s Deputy Foreign Minister for Political Affairs, Majid Takht-Ravanchi, who is in Islamabad for the 13th round of bilateral political consultations, met on Monday with Pakistan’s Foreign Minister Senator Mohammad Ishaq Dar.

title: Iran’s deputy FM in Pakistan for political consultations
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Majid Takht-Ravanchi, Iran’s Deputy Foreign Minister for Political Affairs, arrived in Islamabad to participate in the 13th round of bilateral political consultations between Iran and Pakistan.

title: VP Aref departs for Russia to attend SCO meeting
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Iranian First Vice President left Tehran for Moscow on Monday morning to attend the 24th Meeting of the Council of Heads of Government of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO).

title: VIDEO: Fire engulfs commercial shops in Baghdad
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – A number of commercial shops in the Al-Talibiya area in eastern Baghdad were engulfed in a large fire.

title: Poland reopens two border crossings with Belarus
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Poland has reopened two border crossings with Belarus.

title: Iran not to renounce its nuclear rights
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Iran’s nuclear chief said the assault on the country’s nuclear facilities marked an unprecedented act in the history of targeting nations’ scientific capabilities, reiterating that Iran will not renounce its nuclear rights.

title: Iran to respond to any new IAEA resolution
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Iran’s Deputy Foreign Minister for Legal and International Affairs, Kazem Gharibabadi, says that Iran will respond to any new resolution adopted against it at the IAEA Board of Governors session.

title: Tehran condemns ongoing Gaza siege
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Iran’s Foreign Ministry spokesperson condemned the continued killing of Palestinians and severe human rights violations in Gaza and the West Bank, calling the ongoing siege and destruction a continuation of genocidal policies.

title: Front pages of Iran's English dailies on November 17
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 17 (MNA) – Here are the front pages of Iran's English language dailies on Monday, November 17.

title: Iran FM, PGCC secretary general confer on ties, region
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 16 (MNA) – Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi has held a phone call with the Secretary General of the Persian Gulf Cooperation Council (PGCC) to discuss issues of mutual interest as well as regional developments.

title: Iran, Poland women’s futsal draw in friendly
summary: TEHRAN, Nov. 16 (MNA) – Iran and Poland’s women’s futsal teams played to a 1-1 draw in a friendly on Sunday at the Ynares Sports Arena in Pasig, Philippines.

title: ۹۶ میلیارد دلار ارز حاصل از صادرات به کشور باز نمی گردد
summary: عضو کمیسیون کشاورزی مجلس گفت: ۹۶ میلیارد دلار ارز حاصل از صادرات به کشور برگشت نمی‌شود. چرا این منابع نباید در تولید تزریق شود؟

title: اعلام برنامه زمانبندی رقابت های فوتبال زیر ۱۸ سال دختران کافا
summary: از سوی فدراسیون مرکزی آسیا (کافا) برنامه زمانبندی مسابقات زیر ۱۸ سال دختران ۲۰۲۵ اعلام شد.

title: تأخیر در سد نرماب تبعات اجتماعی و مالی دارد
summary: گرگان-رئیس‌کل دادگستری گلستان گفت: دستگاه قضایی با رفع موانع حقوقی، از روند اجرای پروژه سدنرماب حمایت می‌کند؛چنین طرح‌هایی بار مالی مضاعف و تنش‌های اجتماعی به‌ویژه در حوزه آب ایجاد می‌کند.

title: راهنمای جامع انتخاب لیفتراک در شیراز
summary: انتخاب لیفتراک مناسب می‌تواند سرعت عملیات انبارداری را تا چندین برابر افزایش دهد و از تحمیل هزینه‌های سنگین تعمیرات جلوگیری کند. با ما برای یک معرفی جامع همراه باشید.

title: روایت سخنگوی سپاه از لحظه آغاز عملیات وعده صادق ۳
summary: سردار نائینی سخنگوی سپاه پاسداران گفت: ساعت ۴ برای وعده صادق ۳ آماده بودیم اما تدبیر این شد که پس از انتصاب فرمانده جدید سپاه عملیات انجام شود.

title: پیر غلام حسینی (ع) خرم‌آباد تکریم شد
summary: خرم‌آباد - «حاج عباسعلی مرادی» مداح و پیر غلام حسینی (ع) خرم‌آباد تکریم شد.
